Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Jacob Mason Heberling
Proposal Number 1612079

This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to J. Mason Heberling is "Leveraging centuries of herbarium data to track plant invasion processes: trait shifts, local adaptation, and rapid evolution." The host institutions for this fellowship are the Carnegie Museum of Natural History and the University of Tennessee Knoxville, and the sponsoring scientists are Drs. Stephen Tonsor and Susan Kalisz.

The goal of this research is to understand fundamental plant invasion processes, including the frequency and importance of trait shifts following plant introductions, the direction and rate of these potential trait changes, and the degree to which local adaptation influences invasion success. Globalization of human activities has reshuffled plant communities across the world, resulting in substantial environmental damage and economic losses. In this research, the Fellow is leveraging centuries of biological collections alongside recent advances in functional trait ecology to understand fundamental plant invasion processes. Specifically, the Fellow is utilizing the extensive collection of the Carnegie Museum of Natural History herbarium, supplemented with specimens from other herbaria worldwide. The Fellow is using these specimens of introduced and native Eastern US species, collected from early 1800s to today, to measure traits relating to carbon gain, resource-use, reproductive/dispersal ability, and phenology across space and time. The main research objectives include using these data to track phenotypic change through the course of plant invasion and assess the role of local adaption to understand and predict species success. The Fellow's project fosters the use of herbaria in the rising field of trait-based ecology, and will substantially expand existing global trait databases to facilitate research on fundamental biological questions at a large scale.

The Fellow is receiving training in skills associated with herbarium methods, recent statistical advancements, geographic information systems (GIS), and software development for efficient specimen georeferencing. Career development activities include building research collaborations, developing a broad research portfolio to include herbarium data and evolutionary analyses, and encouraging diverse participation to highlight the importance of biological collections as a vital source of knowledge to the broader community. The Fellow is promoting the use of collections-based research through interaction with community organizations in Western PA, including local elementary education programs and museum docent training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Traits that impact fitness indirectly through effects on performance, also known as functional traits, have been instrumental to understanding invasion success, informing management and restoration practices and predicting which species will become invasive. This fellowship pioneered an approach to fill a critical research void on the role of functional trait change and adaptation during invasion by leveraging data for from thousands of herbarium specimens for 28 non-native, invasive species in Pennsylvania collected over the past 130+ years. It was found that not all species have similar functional trait responses through the course of invasion, with some species exhibiting no changes in measured functional traits since their introduction to the region while others showed significant leaf morphological and chemical differences through time. Some trait shifts may be due to expansion into new habitats and/or environmental changes. This fellowship-supported research showcased the potential for the use of herbarium specimens to quantify trait changes across many species across the world and through time. These results motivate new hypotheses on post-introduction trait shits in invasive species across broader geographic and temporal scales, and future work to understand mechanisms behind these trait shifts.  

Relatively few studies in invasion biology have utilized herbarium specimens as a source of trait data. More broadly, biological collections are underutilized in ecology and herbarium-based functional trait studies are uncommon, although  immense data is ready to be uncovered in herbaria. Despite rapid growth of innovative specimen uses, our understanding of the past trends and the future outlook on the uses of herbarium specimens are limited. A major outcome of this fellowship arose from a computational text analysis of more than 13,000 studies published from 1923-2017 to quantify the dynamic roles of herbaria. Although maintaining its taxonomic core, this literature has functionally diversified from few dominant research topics a century ago to many distinct topics today, with many novel topics only emerging in recent years (such as DNA studies, global change biology, and biodiversity informatics). This synthesis provided evidence to document and promote the diversification of museum collections-based studies.

Over 900 herbarium specimens were collected by the fellow and deposited in the Carnegie Museum Herbarium (CM), with special emphasis on collecting invasive species to enable contemporary comparison with historic specimens. A major limitation in using herbarium specimens for functional trait analyses is rarely knowing the microsite conditions in which the specimen was collected (e.g., shade vs. sun). To directly address this issue, the fellow developed a new protocol for the collection of new specimens using the popular citizen scientist platform, iNaturalist, to link field images and other data to new plant collections. This protocol also improves efficiency of all steps from the collecting event to specimen curation and enhances the potential value of specimens for future use.

Another significant result of this project included demonstrating that herbarium specimen roots can be utilized as a source of data on belowground microbial communities. Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi form close associations with many important plant species and are critical to the functioning of many ecosystems. However, the long-term effects of global change on belowground mutualistic fungi is largely unknown. Further, leading hypotheses on the success of certain invasive species involve these belowground interactions. Sampling specimen roots from several forest species collected in Pennsylvania between 1881-2008, it was found that fungal DNA from herbarium specimen roots can be reliably measured, with successful measurements for specimens as old as 137 years. This study highlighted a new role for herbarium specimens as sources of belowground microbial data to answer questions at vast geographic, temporal, and taxonomic scales.

These projects enabled fellow training and professional development in a new research area and career development. With limited prior experience in herbarium-based research, this fellowship launched an innovative research direction and solidified experience in museum practice for the fellow. This project substantially contributed to the fellow's current career as a museum curator and researcher.

 Beyond professional development for the fellow, activities included outcomes in outreach that disseminated research results and the importance of biological collections to a broader audience. An online blog series Collected On This Day was created with weekly posts featuring a different specimen from the CM collection that was collected on that calendar date. Posts were further distributed in collaboration with the Carnegie Museum of Natural History Marketing Department to museum social media platforms and blogs. Fellowship research results and themes were integrated into programs at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History, including interactive live streamed videos from the herbarium, contribution to summer camp programs in collaboration with museum educators, and museum docent training. Specimens collected during this research were also included in an exhibition on the impacts of humans in the Anthropocene and remain on permanent display in Botany Hall at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History.
